data.title: Miro Babin's Post - LinkedIn
data.snippet:
# Miro Babinâ€™s Post

Miro Babin

 Report this post

Proud to celebrate an outstanding performance of the Amherst College teamâ€”Andreas Rasvanis, Sherry Jiang, and Claudiu Babinâ€”at the 2024 ICPC Northeast Regional this past Sunday! Competing on-site against 105 teams from universities across New England and five Canadian provinces, our team took 1st place among undergraduate institutions and 16th place overall, solving 8 out of 13 problems. A huge thank you to the organizers and sponsors for making this event possible, as well as to the Amherst CS department for their invaluable support. Special shoutout to Jane Street for the Robert Frost inspired t-shirt!

data.title: [PDF] Semiannual Report April 1, 1997 through September 30, 1997
data.snippet:
The main reason for this inefficiency is theinadequate treatment of thevarious nonelliptic factors of the Euleror Navicr-Stokes system of equations, andespecially therelatively shortdistance to whichsmooth character-isticcomponents areapproximated oncoarse grids.Othercomputational obstacles have alsofailedto be systematically studied andtreated.Ourobjective nowhasbeen to firstprcparc acomprehensive listof all these obstacles, theirpossible treatments and current states ofdevelopment, and thento push systematically toward theirresolution. [...] The corresponding FMG algorithm yields a solution withthediscretization accuracy injust5minimal workunits.Wehave also cxpcrimcntcd with thediscrete full potential operator in the deep supersonic regime (M 2 > 2, where M is the Mach number).
Wc havc developed and tcstcd an efficient predictor-corrector solver for this problem.
Numerical experiments showed that this solver, when combined with the transonic full potential operator solver developed earlier gives us a textbook-efficient multigrid solver for the full potential operator at all Mach numbcrs.
Our main goal remains to solve the Eulcr system with textbook multigrid efficiency. [...] I also interacted withothers at NASALangeley with common interests, including K. Anderson andanumber ofresearchers intheMDOBranch (P.Newman, J.
Barthclemy, L. Green, N.Alexandrov, G.Hou,andC. Gumbcrt).
Workwill continue onimplementing optimization-friendly parallel prec0nditioners, whichwill greatly reduce runtimesandallow solution ofmorcrealistic problems.
Plans have been made fortheCMUEarth-quake Modeling GrandChallenge groupto usetheICASE parallelunstructured volume renderer whenit becomes available for theCrayT3E.Thiswill allowusto doon-line rendering, thereby significantly in-creasing theresolution of ourearthquake wave propagation visualizations, whichhave been limitedby the sequential rendering toolswe've used.
